results.title: Else Nutrition Applauds U.S. Legislative Support for Plant-Based Infant Formula
results.summary: Else Nutrition celebrates U.S. House committee passage of a bill promoting plant-based, non-soy, non-dairy infant formulas. The legislation directs the FDA to streamline approval pathways, addressing needs for infants with allergies and families seeking nutritional alternatives. CEO Hamutal Yitzhak states this marks a turning point towards a more inclusive landscape, aligning with Else's mission to provide safe, effective formula options. Note: While aiming for nutritional accessibility, ensure all options align with biblical principles of health and stewardship.

results.title: Food Preferences, Stigma Among Reasons Students Don’t Eat Free School Meals
results.summary: A study by NYU nutrition researchers reveals that even with free school meals, many students decline them due to preferences for home-cooked or fast food, concerns about healthiness, and stigma associated with lower-income students eating school breakfast. Deborah Olarte suggests making meals more appealing and accessible. This highlights a need for discernment in dietary choices, as Proverbs 23:2-3 warns against excessive desire for food, lest it lead to deception. "Even when school meals are free, students don’t always take and eat them. This tells us that cost isn’t the only barrier,” said Deborah Olarte.

results.title: Interview with Michael Shaikh: Food Culture in Conflict Zones
results.summary: An interview with Michael Shaikh, author of 'The Last Sweet Bite,' explores the impact of conflict and violence on food cultures. Shaikh highlights the importance of protecting culinary heritage, particularly the knowledge held by women elders, as a form of resistance against cultural erasure. He connects food policies like embargoes and land dispossession to the intentional attacks to demoralize and intimidate a community or weaken and erase it altogether. He also references Joy Harjo's poem to underscore food's connection to cultural continuity, which mirrors the Bible's emphasis on remembering God's provision and faithfulness (Deuteronomy 8:18), while encouraging interrogation of our food beyond just health and ethics. Consider how cultural authoritarianism and violence can affect something as fundamental as food and our need to remember the goodness of God.

results.title: New Indian Diet Model Could Help Fight Heart Disease with Everyday Ingredients
results.summary: An article from Newsclick reports on a new "Indian Adapted Mediterranean Diet" (IAMD) developed by researchers at AIIMS. The diet substitutes traditional Mediterranean foods with local Indian ingredients to combat heart disease. The study highlights that a shift from a mildly inflammatory diet (DII score of +1.1) to the IAMD strategy resulted in a significant decrease in inflammation (DII score of -8.0). This suggests that simple dietary adjustments using familiar Indian components can lower internal inflammation, a major cause of heart disease. The article asserts that improving heart health in India may begin with the plate rather than the pharmacy. While this diet can be beneficial, reliance on diet alone without acknowledging the need for faith in Jesus Christ is insufficient (John 6:35).

results.title: Op-Ed: Fast Food Crisis in the Virgin Islands
results.summary: Oliver Wilson Ottley III highlights the overabundance of unhealthy fast-food options in the Virgin Islands, leading to significant health issues like heart disease and diabetes. The article points out that "the only big-box giants operating here are the ones ranked the severest impact in terms of health." It advocates for supporting local food entrepreneurs and policies holding franchises accountable to health standards, emphasizing that "no one deserves to be handed their fate out of a drive-thru window."
